svg.content: <mxfile host="Electron" agent="Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) draw.io/27.0.9 Chrome/134.0.6998.205 Electron/35.4.0 Safari/537.36" scale="1" border="0" version="27.0.9"> <diagram id="complete-framework-diagram" name="Apex Thinking Tools Framework (Complete)"> <mxGraphModel dx="1891" dy="1109" grid="1" gridSize="10" guides="1" tooltips="1" connect="1" arrows="1" fold="1" page="1" pageScale="1" pageWidth="4000" pageHeight="5500" math="0" shadow="0"> <root> <mxCell id="0" /> <mxCell id="1" parent="0" /> <mxCell id="title" value="Apex Thinking Tools Framework - Enhanced Edition (Complete)" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=none;fillColor=none;align=center;verticalAlign=middle;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=0;fontSize=24;fontStyle=1;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="40" y="20" width="3620" height="40" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="phase-C1" value="C1: Structured Idea Evaluation & Analysis" style="shape=swimlane;fontStyle=1;childLayout=stackLayout;horizontal=1;startSize=40;horizontalStack=0;resizeParent=1;resizeParentMax=0;resizeLast=0;collapsible=1;marginBottom=0;fillColor=#dae8fc;strokeColor=#6c8ebf;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="40" y="100" width="350" height="3960" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T1_1" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>PMI (Plus, Minus, Interesting)</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Edward de Bono (DATT/CoRT)<br/><b>Category:</b> Analysis/Evaluation<br/><b>Purpose:</b> To explore all sides of an idea or proposal beyond initial emotional reactions. <br/><b>Input:</b> Any new idea, suggestion, or topic requiring objective evaluation.<br/><b>Process:</b> Systematically list all positive points (Plus), negative points (Minus), and noteworthy points (Interesting). <br/><b>Output:</b> A balanced, objective view of an idea, preventing premature judgment. </div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#6c8ebf;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="40" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T1_2" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>CAF (Consider All Factors)</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Edward de Bono (DATT/CoRT)<br/><b>Category:</b> Analysis/Evaluation<br/><b>Purpose:</b> To ensure a thorough exploration of all relevant factors in a situation or decision. [2, 3]<br/><b>Input:</b> A decision, plan, or situation that needs to be fully understood.<br/><b>Process:</b> Deliberately list every factor that should be considered, looking beyond the obvious. <br/><b>Output:</b> A comprehensive list of factors, ensuring a broad and well-rounded perspective. </div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#6c8ebf;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="310" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T1_3" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>C&amp;S (Consequence and Sequel)</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Edward de Bono (DATT/CoRT)<br/><b>Category:</b> Analysis/Evaluation<br/><b>Purpose:</b> To look ahead and anticipate the future outcomes of an action or decision. [6, 24]<br/><b>Input:</b> A proposed action, plan, or decision.<br/><b>Process:</b> Systematically consider the immediate, short-term, medium-term, and long-term consequences. [3, 24]<br/><b>Output:</b> A clear view of the potential future impacts, enabling better evaluation and planning. </div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#6c8ebf;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="580" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T1_4" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>AGO (Aims, Goals, Objectives)</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Edward de Bono (DATT/CoRT)<br/><b>Category:</b> Direction Setting<br/><b>Purpose:</b> To clarify the precise purpose and intention behind any thinking activity. [17, 27]<br/><b>Input:</b> The start of any thinking task, meeting, or project.<br/><b>Process:</b> Deliberately define what you are trying to achieve and why. <br/><b>Output:</b> A clear, focused statement of purpose that guides all subsequent thinking. </div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#6c8ebf;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="850" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T1_5" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>FIP (First Important Priorities)</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Edward de Bono (DATT/CoRT)<br/><b>Category:</b> Planning/Decision<br/><b>Purpose:</b> To select the most important ideas, factors, or objectives from a longer list. <br/><b>Input:</b> A list of ideas, factors, or options generated by other tools (e.g., CAF, PMI).<br/><b>Process:</b> Systematically evaluate and choose the items that are most critical or must be addressed first. <br/><b>Output:</b> A ranked or selected list of priorities to focus action and decision-making. </div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#6c8ebf;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="1120" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T1_6" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>APC (Alternatives, Possibilities, Choices)</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Edward de Bono (DATT/CoRT)<br/><b>Category:</b> Creative Ideation<br/><b>Purpose:</b> To deliberately search for more alternatives beyond the obvious ones. <br/><b>Input:</b> A problem, decision, or situation where new options are needed.<br/><b>Process:</b> Make a conscious effort to generate multiple possibilities, choices, or alternative explanations. <br/><b>Output:</b> A broader range of options, preventing being locked into a limited view. </div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#6c8ebf;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="1390" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T1_7" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>OPV (Other People's Views)</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Edward de Bono (DATT/CoRT)<br/><b>Category:</b> Perspective Shifting<br/><b>Purpose:</b> To deliberately explore the viewpoints of other people involved in a situation. [12, 28]<br/><b>Input:</b> Any situation involving multiple stakeholders.<br/><b>Process:</b> Identify all relevant people and then make a conscious effort to see the situation from their perspective. [20, 21]<br/><b>Output:</b> A broader, more empathetic understanding of the situation, leading to better solutions. </div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#6c8ebf;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="1660" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T1_8" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>KVI (Key Values Involved)</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Edward de Bono (DATT/CoRT)<br/><b>Category:</b> Analysis/Evaluation<br/><b>Purpose:</b> To identify the underlying values that are shaping a decision or viewpoint.<br/><b>Input:</b> A complex decision, conflict, or situation where motivations are unclear.<br/><b>Process:</b> Analyze the situation to explicitly state which values (e.g., safety, profit, fairness) are at play and how they conflict or align.<br/><b>Output:</b> Clarity on the core values driving the thinking, helping to resolve conflicts and make value-consistent decisions.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#6c8ebf;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="1930" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T1_9" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>RAD (Recognise, Analyse, Divide)</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Edward de Bono (DATT/CoRT)<br/><b>Category:</b> Analysis/Evaluation<br/><b>Purpose:</b> To break down a large, complex concept into smaller, more manageable parts. <br/><b>Input:</b> A large or confusing topic, problem, or area of thought.<br/><b>Process:</b> Recognize the main components, analyze their relationships, and divide the overall concept into distinct sub-parts. <br/><b>Output:</b> A structured breakdown of a complex subject, making it easier to understand and address.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#6c8ebf;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="2200" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T1_10" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>DOCA (Design/Decision, Outcome, Channels, Action)</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Edward de Bono (DATT/CoRT)<br/><b>Category:</b> Planning/Decision<br/><b>Purpose:</b> To structure the output of a thinking session into a concrete plan. <br/><b>Input:</b> The conclusion of a problem-solving or decision-making process.<br/><b>Process:</b> Clearly state the final Decision, the desired Outcome, the Channels for implementation, and the specific Action steps. <br/><b>Output:</b> A clear, actionable plan that translates a decision into concrete next steps.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#6c8ebf;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="2470" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T1_11" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Jobs-to-be-Done (JTBD) Analysis</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Clayton Christensen &amp; Tony Ulwick (1990s-2000s)<br/><b>Category:</b> Analysis/Evaluation<br/><b>Purpose:</b> Analyzes the underlying motivations of customers using a product or service.<br/><b>Input:</b> A product, service, or market segment needing deeper customer understanding.<br/><b>Process:</b> Interview customers to map their journey and identify unmet needs.<br/><b>Output:</b> A map of customer jobs with clear opportunities for innovation.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#6c8ebf;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="2740" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T1_12" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Cynefin Framework</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Dave Snowden (1999, IBM)<br/><b>Category:</b> Analysis/Evaluation<br/><b>Purpose:</b> Categorizes problems into five domains to guide decision-making.<br/><b>Input:</b> Any decision-making situation, especially complex or ambiguous ones.<br/><b>Process:</b> Assess if a problem is Simple, Complicated, Complex, Chaotic, or in Disorder.<br/><b>Output:</b> A clear problem categorization and a tailored strategy for action.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#6c8ebf;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="3010" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T1_13" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Pre-mortem Analysis</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Gary Klein (1998)<br/><b>Category:</b> Analysis/Evaluation<br/><b>Purpose:</b> Imagines a future failure to proactively identify and mitigate risks.<br/><b>Input:</b> Any project, plan, or decision before its implementation.<br/><b>Process:</b> Assume the project has failed and brainstorm all possible reasons why.<br/><b>Output:</b> A comprehensive risk register with preventive and contingency plans.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#6c8ebf;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="3280" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T1_14" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Causal Loop Diagrams</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> System Dynamics (Jay Forrester, 1950s)<br/><b>Category:</b> Analysis/Evaluation<br/><b>Purpose:</b> Visualizes interconnected feedback loops in complex systems.<br/><b>Input:</b> Complex problems with multiple interacting factors and feedback effects.<br/><b>Process:</b> Map key variables and their causal relationships to identify feedback loops.<br/><b>Output:</b> A visual map of system dynamics, highlighting leverage points for intervention.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#6c8ebf;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="3550" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="phase-C2" value="C2: Creative Idea Generation &amp; Exploration" style="shape=swimlane;fontStyle=1;childLayout=stackLayout;horizontal=1;startSize=40;horizontalStack=0;resizeParent=1;resizeParentMax=0;resizeLast=0;collapsible=1;marginBottom=0;fillColor=#d5e8d4;strokeColor=#82b366;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="410" y="100" width="350" height="2200" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T2_1-placeholder" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Lateral Thinking</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Edward de Bono<br/><b>Category:</b> Creative Ideation<br/><b>Purpose:</b> To solve problems through indirect and creative approaches, avoiding obvious step-by-step logic.<br/><b>Input:</b> Problems where traditional approaches have failed or new perspectives are needed.<br/><b>Process:</b> Use techniques like provocation, random entry, and challenging assumptions to move 'sideways' to new ideas.<br/><b>Output:</b> Novel solutions and insights that are not attainable through conventional thinking.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#82b366;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C2" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="40" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T2_2-placeholder" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Brainstorming</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Alex Faickney Osborn (1939)<br/><b>Category:</b> Creative Ideation<br/><b>Purpose:</b> To generate a large number of ideas in a group setting without criticism.<br/><b>Input:</b> A specific problem or topic requiring a wide range of ideas.<br/><b>Process:</b> A group spontaneously contributes ideas, deferring judgment and building on others' suggestions.<br/><b>Output:</b> A vast quantity of diverse ideas to be evaluated and refined later.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#82b366;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C2" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="310" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T2_14" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>TRIZ (Theory of Inventive Problem Solving)</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Genrich Altshuller (1946-1970s, Soviet Union)<br/><b>Category:</b> Creative Ideation<br/><b>Purpose:</b> A systematic innovation method to solve problems with contradictions.<br/><b>Input:</b> Problems with technical or physical contradictions (improving A worsens B).<br/><b>Process:</b> Define contradictions and apply TRIZ principles to resolve them without compromise.<br/><b>Output:</b> Innovative solutions that resolve core contradictions.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#82b366;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C2" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="580" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T2_15" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Biomimicry Thinking</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Janine Benyus (1997)<br/><b>Category:</b> Creative Ideation<br/><b>Purpose:</b> Solves human problems by emulating nature's time-tested strategies.<br/><b>Input:</b> Any design challenge, especially those involving sustainability or efficiency.<br/><b>Process:</b> Define a function, research how nature performs it, and abstract the principle.<br/><b>Output:</b> Bio-inspired solutions that are often sustainable and highly efficient.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#82b366;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C2" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="850" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T2_16" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Morphological Analysis</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Fritz Zwicky (1940s, Caltech)<br/><b>Category:</b> Creative Ideation<br/><b>Purpose:</b> Systematically explores all possible solutions in a complex problem space.<br/><b>Input:</b> Complex problems with multiple independent parameters.<br/><b>Process:</b> Decompose a problem into parameters and combine options for each.<br/><b>Output:</b> A map of the solution space, including unexpected combinations.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#82b366;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C2" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="1120" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T2_17" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Design Sprint</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Jake Knapp (Google Ventures, 2010)<br/><b>Category:</b> Creative Ideation<br/><b>Purpose:</b> Compresses months of work into a five-day rapid prototyping and testing cycle.<br/><b>Input:</b> Big challenges, new product ideas, or features needing rapid validation.<br/><b>Process:</b> Follow the five-day structure: Map, Sketch, Decide, Prototype, Test.<br/><b>Output:</b> A tested prototype and validated learning based on real customer feedback.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#82b366;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C2" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="1390" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T2_18" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Oblique Strategies</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Brian Eno &amp; Peter Schmidt (1975)<br/><b>Category:</b> Creative Ideation<br/><b>Purpose:</b> Breaks creative blocks using cryptic suggestions to prompt new thinking.<br/><b>Input:</b> Any situation where creative thinking is blocked or stuck in a rut.<br/><b>Process:</b> When stuck, draw a random card and apply its abstract suggestion to the problem.<br/><b>Output:</b> Unexpected creative breakthroughs by forcing radical perspective shifts.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#82b366;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C2" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="1660" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T2_19" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Assumption Reversal</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Creative Problem Solving tradition<br/><b>Category:</b> Creative Ideation<br/><b>Purpose:</b> Generates innovative ideas by identifying and reversing core assumptions.<br/><b>Input:</b> Problems where conventional thinking has reached its limits.<br/><b>Process:</b> List all assumptions about a problem, reverse each one, and explore the results.<br/><b>Output:</b> Disruptive ideas that challenge industry norms and unlock new possibilities.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#82b366;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C2" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="1930" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="phase-C3" value="C3: Perspective Shifting &amp; Direction Setting" style="shape=swimlane;fontStyle=1;childLayout=stackLayout;horizontal=1;startSize=40;horizontalStack=0;resizeParent=1;resizeParentMax=0;resizeLast=0;collapsible=1;marginBottom=0;fillColor=#fff2cc;strokeColor=#d6b656;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="780" y="100" width="350" height="1400" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T3_1" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Six Thinking Hats</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Edward de Bono<br/><b>Category:</b> Perspective Shifting<br/><b>Purpose:</b> To look at a decision from multiple perspectives, ensuring a rounded view.<br/><b>Input:</b> A complex decision or problem requiring group alignment and thorough exploration.<br/><b>Process:</b> The group metaphorically wears different colored 'hats' (e.g., White for facts, Red for emotions, Black for caution) to focus thinking on one aspect at a time.<br/><b>Output:</b> A well-rounded decision that has been examined from all key perspectives, reducing conflict and improving outcomes.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#d6b656;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C3" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="40" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T3_10" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Futures Wheel</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Jerome Glenn (1972)<br/><b>Category:</b> Perspective Shifting<br/><b>Purpose:</b> Visualizes the direct and indirect consequences of a decision or change.<br/><b>Input:</b> Any significant change, trend, or decision that requires understanding ripple effects.<br/><b>Process:</b> Map primary, secondary, and tertiary impacts of a central event in a radial diagram.<br/><b>Output:</b> A visual map of cascading consequences, revealing unexpected impacts.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#d6b656;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C3" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="310" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T3_11" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Polarity Management</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Barry Johnson (1992)<br/><b>Category:</b> Perspective Shifting<br/><b>Purpose:</b> Manages unsolvable tensions between two interdependent opposites (polarities).<br/><b>Input:</b> Ongoing tensions like centralization vs. decentralization, or stability vs. change.<br/><b>Process:</b> Map the benefits and downsides of each pole to manage the tension, not solve it.<br/><b>Output:</b> A strategy to leverage both poles, turning 'either/or' conflicts into 'both/and' management.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#d6b656;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C3" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="580" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T3_12" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Appreciative Inquiry</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> David Cooperrider &amp; Suresh Srivastva (1987)<br/><b>Category:</b> Perspective Shifting<br/><b>Purpose:</b> Shifts focus from problems to possibilities by exploring what is working well.<br/><b>Input:</b> Organizational change or team development situations needing positive momentum.<br/><b>Process:</b> Follow the 4-D cycle: Discover (what works), Dream (what could be), Design, Destiny.<br/><b>Output:</b> A positive vision for the future based on amplifying existing strengths.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#d6b656;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C3" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="850" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T3_13" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Dialectical Thinking</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Hegelian dialectics, adapted for problem-solving<br/><b>Category:</b> Perspective Shifting<br/><b>Purpose:</b> Resolves contradictions by creating a higher-order synthesis of opposing views.<br/><b>Input:</b> Conflicts between opposing ideas, paradoxes, or incompatible requirements.<br/><b>Process:</b> Explore the truth in a thesis and its antithesis to create a new synthesis.<br/><b>Output:</b> Higher-order solutions that transcend the initial contradiction.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#d6b656;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C3" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="1120" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="phase-C4" value="C4: Action &amp; Implementation Planning" style="shape=swimlane;fontStyle=1;childLayout=stackLayout;horizontal=1;startSize=40;horizontalStack=0;resizeParent=1;resizeParentMax=0;resizeLast=0;collapsible=1;marginBottom=0;fillColor=#f8cecc;strokeColor=#b85450;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="1150" y="100" width="350" height="1670" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T4_1" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Action Planning</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Foundational management principle<br/><b>Category:</b> Planning/Decision<br/><b>Purpose:</b> To translate a decision or goal into a concrete sequence of steps.<br/><b>Input:</b> A defined goal, objective, or decision.<br/><b>Process:</b> Define specific tasks, assign responsibilities, set timelines, and allocate resources needed to achieve the goal.<br/><b>Output:</b> A detailed, documented plan that outlines who will do what, by when, to ensure implementation.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#b85450;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C4" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="40" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T4_6" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>OKRs (Objectives and Key Results)</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Andy Grove (Intel, 1970s), popularized by John Doerr<br/><b>Category:</b> Planning/Decision<br/><b>Purpose:</b> Aligns and engages teams around measurable, ambitious goals.<br/><b>Input:</b> Strategic planning and goal setting for organizations, teams, or individuals.<br/><b>Process:</b> Set ambitious Objectives (what) and measurable Key Results (how).<br/><b>Output:</b> Clear, measurable goals that are aligned across the entire organization.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#b85450;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C4" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="310" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T4_7" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Lean Canvas</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Ash Maurya (2010), adapted from Business Model Canvas<br/><b>Category:</b> Planning/Decision<br/><b>Purpose:</b> A one-page business model for startups focusing on problems and solutions.<br/><b>Input:</b> New business ideas, startup plans, or internal innovation projects.<br/><b>Process:</b> Systematically fill out the nine blocks, starting with problem and customer segments.<br/><b>Output:</b> A concise, one-page business model that highlights the riskiest assumptions to test.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#b85450;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C4" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="580" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T4_8" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Monte Carlo Simulation</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Stanislaw Ulam &amp; John von Neumann (1940s)<br/><b>Category:</b> Planning/Decision<br/><b>Purpose:</b> Evaluates the probability of different outcomes in uncertain scenarios.<br/><b>Input:</b> Complex decisions with multiple uncertainties, like financial forecasting.<br/><b>Process:</b> Run thousands of simulations with randomized inputs to analyze outcomes.<br/><b>Output:</b> A probability distribution of potential outcomes, not just a single estimate.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#b85450;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C4" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="850" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T4_9" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Wardley Mapping</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Simon Wardley (2005)<br/><b>Category:</b> Planning/Decision<br/><b>Purpose:</b> Visualizes a business's structure to inform strategic decisions.<br/><b>Input:</b> Strategic planning, technology decisions, or competitive analysis.<br/><b>Process:</b> Map a value chain against its evolutionary stage (from genesis to commodity).<br/><b>Output:</b> A visual map of the competitive landscape and where to invest or adapt.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#b85450;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C4" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="1120" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T4_10" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Decision Matrix (Weighted Scoring)</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Operations Research field<br/><b>Category:</b> Planning/Decision<br/><b>Purpose:</b> Objectively evaluates multiple options against weighted criteria.<br/><b>Input:</b> Multi-criteria decisions like vendor selection, hiring, or technology choices.<br/><b>Process:</b> List options and criteria, weight the criteria, and score each option.<br/><b>Output:</b> A quantitative ranking of options with transparent, documented reasoning.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#b85450;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C4" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="1390" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="phase-C5" value="C5: Hybrid &amp; Cutting-Edge Approaches" style="shape=swimlane;fontStyle=1;childLayout=stackLayout;horizontal=1;startSize=40;horizontalStack=0;resizeParent=1;resizeParentMax=0;resizeLast=0;collapsible=1;marginBottom=0;fillColor=#e1d5e7;strokeColor=#9673a6;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="1520" y="100" width="350" height="2200" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T5_1" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>AI-Augmented Ideation</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Emerging practice (2020s)<br/><b>Category:</b> Hybrid Approaches<br/><b>Purpose:</b> Combines human creativity with AI to generate and refine ideas at scale.<br/><b>Input:</b> Any creative challenge that would benefit from rapid, large-scale exploration.<br/><b>Process:</b> Use AI as a creative partner to generate, expand, and challenge ideas.<br/><b>Output:</b> A large volume of diverse and novel ideas refined through human-AI collaboration.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#9673a6;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C5" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="40" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T5_2" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Quantum Thinking</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Inspired by quantum mechanics principles (2010s)<br/><b>Category:</b> Hybrid Approaches<br/><b>Purpose:</b> Applies quantum concepts (e.g., superposition) to explore non-linear solutions.<br/><b>Input:</b> Complex problems with paradoxes and systems with observer effects.<br/><b>Process:</b> Suspend classical logic to hold multiple contradictory ideas as simultaneously true.<br/><b>Output:</b> Solutions that transcend classical logic by leveraging paradox and uncertainty.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#9673a6;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C5" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="310" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T5_3" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Complexity Science Toolkit</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Santa Fe Institute (1980s-present)<br/><b>Category:</b> Hybrid Approaches<br/><b>Purpose:</b> Applies complexity science to understand and influence complex adaptive systems.<br/><b>Input:</b> Organizational change, market dynamics, or other complex adaptive systems.<br/><b>Process:</b> Map system agents and interactions to find leverage points and emergent patterns.<br/><b>Output:</b> An understanding of system dynamics and strategies that work with complexity.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#9673a6;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C5" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="580" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T5_4" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Narrative Scenario Planning</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Shell Oil (1970s), evolved with narrative methods<br/><b>Category:</b> Hybrid Approaches<br/><b>Purpose:</b> Creates multiple detailed future stories to prepare for different possibilities.<br/><b>Input:</b> Strategic planning under high uncertainty or long-term risk management.<br/><b>Process:</b> Identify key uncertainties, create a scenario matrix, and develop rich narratives.<br/><b>Output:</b> Distinct future narratives and robust strategies that work across multiple scenarios.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#9673a6;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C5" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="850" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T5_5" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Regenerative Design Thinking</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Regenerative development movement (2000s)<br/><b>Category:</b> Hybrid Approaches<br/><b>Purpose:</b> Creates solutions that actively restore and regenerate social and ecological systems.<br/><b>Input:</b> Any design challenge where long-term systemic health is a priority.<br/><b>Process:</b> Design solutions that give back more than they take, creating positive spirals.<br/><b>Output:</b> Solutions that heal systems while solving problems, creating long-term value.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#9673a6;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C5" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="1120" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T5_6" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Antifragile Strategy Design</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Nassim Taleb's Antifragility concept (2012)<br/><b>Category:</b> Hybrid Approaches<br/><b>Purpose:</b> Creates strategies that gain from disorder and become stronger under stress.<br/><b>Input:</b> Strategy design in uncertain environments, risk management, innovation planning.<br/><b>Process:</b> Design systems with optionality and redundancy to benefit from volatility.<br/><b>Output:</b> Strategies that improve with stress and evolve through challenges.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#9673a6;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C5" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="1390" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T5_7" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Collective Intelligence Design</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> MIT Center for Collective Intelligence (2000s)<br/><b>Category:</b> Hybrid Approaches<br/><b>Purpose:</b> Harnesses group intelligence through processes that aggregate diverse perspectives.<br/><b>Input:</b> Complex problems requiring diverse expertise and democratic decision-making.<br/><b>Process:</b> Structure group processes to maximize cognitive diversity and quality aggregation.<br/><b>Output:</b> Solutions and robust decisions that exceed any individual's capability.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#9673a6;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C5" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="1660" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="tool-T5_8" value="<div style="text-align:left;padding:5px;"><b>Metamodern Synthesis</b><hr/><b>Origin:</b> Metamodern philosophy (2010s)<br/><b>Category:</b> Hybrid Approaches<br/><b>Purpose:</b> Oscillates between modern and postmodern views to create sincere, hopeful solutions.<br/><b>Input:</b> Wicked problems, cultural challenges, and innovation in complex social contexts.<br/><b>Process:</b> Hold multiple perspectives simultaneously, embracing 'both/and' thinking to take action.<br/><b>Output:</b> Nuanced solutions that embrace paradox and enable action despite uncertainty.</div>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=#9673a6;fillColor=#ffffff;align=left;verticalAlign=top;whiteSpace=wrap;rounded=1;shadow=1;" parent="phase-C5" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="1930" width="350" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="arrow-1-2" div.div:
PMI (Plus, Minus, Interesting)Origin: Edward de Bono (DATT/CoRT)
Category: Analysis/Evaluation
Purpose: To explore all sides of an idea or proposal beyond initial emotional reactions.
Input: Any new idea, suggestion, or topic requiring objective evaluation.
Process: Systematically list all positive points (Plus), negative points (Minus), and noteworthy points (Interesting).
Output: A balanced, objective view of an idea, preventing premature judgment.

div.div:
CAF (Consider All Factors)Origin: Edward de Bono (DATT/CoRT)
Category: Analysis/Evaluation
Purpose: To ensure a thorough exploration of all relevant factors in a situation or decision. [2, 3]
Input: A decision, plan, or situation that needs to be fully understood.
Process: Deliberately list every factor that should be considered, looking beyond the obvious.
Output: A comprehensive list of factors, ensuring a broad and well-rounded perspective.

div.div:
C&S (Consequence and Sequel)Origin: Edward de Bono (DATT/CoRT)
Category: Analysis/Evaluation
Purpose: To look ahead and anticipate the future outcomes of an action or decision. [6, 24]
Input: A proposed action, plan, or decision.
Process: Systematically consider the immediate, short-term, medium-term, and long-term consequences. [3, 24]
Output: A clear view of the potential future impacts, enabling better evaluation and planning.

div.div:
AGO (Aims, Goals, Objectives)Origin: Edward de Bono (DATT/CoRT)
Category: Direction Setting
Purpose: To clarify the precise purpose and intention behind any thinking activity. [17, 27]
Input: The start of any thinking task, meeting, or project.
Process: Deliberately define what you are trying to achieve and why.
Output: A clear, focused statement of purpose that guides all subsequent thinking.

FIP (First Important Priorities)Origin: Edward de Bono (DATT/CoRT)
Category: Planning/Decision
Purpose: To select the most important ideas, factors, or objectives from a longer list.
Input: A list of ideas, factors, or options generated by other tools (e.g., CAF, PMI).
Process: Systematically evaluate and choose the items that are most critical or must be addressed first.
Output: A ranked or selected list of priorities to focus action and decision-making.

div.div:
APC (Alternatives, Possibilities, Choices)Origin: Edward de Bono (DATT/CoRT)
Category: Creative Ideation
Purpose: To deliberately search for more alternatives beyond the obvious ones.
Input: A problem, decision, or situation where new options are needed.
Process: Make a conscious effort to generate multiple possibilities, choices, or alternative explanations.
Output: A broader range of options, preventing being locked into a limited view.

div.div:
OPV (Other People's Views)Origin: Edward de Bono (DATT/CoRT)
Category: Perspective Shifting
Purpose: To deliberately explore the viewpoints of other people involved in a situation. [12, 28]
Input: Any situation involving multiple stakeholders.
Process: Identify all relevant people and then make a conscious effort to see the situation from their perspective. [20, 21]
Output: A broader, more empathetic understanding of the situation, leading to better solutions.

div.div:
KVI (Key Values Involved)Origin: Edward de Bono (DATT/CoRT)
Category: Analysis/Evaluation
Purpose: To identify the underlying values that are shaping a decision or viewpoint.
Input: A complex decision, conflict, or situation where motivations are unclear.
Process: Analyze the situation to explicitly state which values (e.g., safety, profit, fairness) are at play and how they conflict or align.
Output: Clarity on the core values driving the thinking, helping to resolve conflicts and make value-consistent decisions.

div.div:
RAD (Recognise, Analyse, Divide)Origin: Edward de Bono (DATT/CoRT)
Category: Analysis/Evaluation
Purpose: To break down a large, complex concept into smaller, more manageable parts.
Input: A large or confusing topic, problem, or area of thought.
Process: Recognize the main components, analyze their relationships, and divide the overall concept into distinct sub-parts.
Output: A structured breakdown of a complex subject, making it easier to understand and address.

div.div:
DOCA (Design/Decision, Outcome, Channels, Action)Origin: Edward de Bono (DATT/CoRT)
Category: Planning/Decision
Purpose: To structure the output of a thinking session into a concrete plan.
Input: The conclusion of a problem-solving or decision-making process.
Process: Clearly state the final Decision, the desired Outcome, the Channels for implementation, and the specific Action steps.
Output: A clear, actionable plan that translates a decision into concrete next steps.

div.div:
Jobs-to-be-Done (JTBD) AnalysisOrigin: Clayton Christensen & Tony Ulwick (1990s-2000s)
Category: Analysis/Evaluation
Purpose: Analyzes the underlying motivations of customers using a product or service.
Input: A product, service, or market segment needing deeper customer understanding.
Process: Interview customers to map their journey and identify unmet needs.
Output: A map of customer jobs with clear opportunities for innovation.

div.div:
Cynefin FrameworkOrigin: Dave Snowden (1999, IBM)
Category: Analysis/Evaluation
Purpose: Categorizes problems into five domains to guide decision-making.
Input: Any decision-making situation, especially complex or ambiguous ones.
Process: Assess if a problem is Simple, Complicated, Complex, Chaotic, or in Disorder.
Output: A clear problem categorization and a tailored strategy for action.

div.div:
Pre-mortem AnalysisOrigin: Gary Klein (1998)
Category: Analysis/Evaluation
Purpose: Imagines a future failure to proactively identify and mitigate risks.
Input: Any project, plan, or decision before its implementation.
Process: Assume the project has failed and brainstorm all possible reasons why.
Output: A comprehensive risk register with preventive and contingency plans.

div.div:
Causal Loop DiagramsOrigin: System Dynamics (Jay Forrester, 1950s)
Category: Analysis/Evaluation
